Description: A hollow terracotta grotesque woman’s head and neck, and an entity in itself, with an elaborate hairstyle, consisting of a roll over the forehead and a loop above, the roll extending round the back, where it is drawn up to a high loop on top of the head. A hole has been bored into the neck for a modern stand. Two-piece mould. Micaceous orange brown Nile silt, with a brown surface. Traces of an overall white dressing, with small touches of pink paint surviving.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: W.L. Hildburgh. Roman, second century AD. Comparandum: Near: Breccia 1934: pl. xcv :530, which may be broken from a figure.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3126)
Acquisition name: Transferred from: Victoria and Albert Museum (Department of Architecture and Sculpture)
Donated by: Dr W L Hildburgh
